text: University of Birmingham School of Mathematics Real Analysis – Integration – Spring 2025 Problem Sheet 5 Model Solutions Instructions: You are strongly encouraged to attempt all of the questions (Q) below, and as many of the extra questions (EQ) as you can, to help prepare for the final exam. Model solutions will only be released for questions Q1-Q4. Q1. (a) Suppose that X ⊆ R is not empty and that N ∈ R is an upper bound for X. Prove that if for each ϵ > 0, there exists x in X such that N − ϵ < x, then N = sup X. (b) Find, with proof, the infimum of the set A := {x : 3 < |x − 2| < 5} (c) Suppose that P = {0, 4, 12, 17, 20} and g : [0, 20] → R is given by g(x) := 3x + 7. (i) Calculate the Riemann–Darboux sums L(g, P ) and U (g, P ). (ii) For each n ∈ N, let Pn denote the partition of [0, 20] into n subintervals of equal width. Find a natural number N such that U (g, PN ) − L(g, PN ) < 1 1,000 . The Riemann–Darboux sums calculator (Spring Week 1 Materials on Canvas) may be helpful in part (c). Solution. (a) Proof. We know that N is an upper bound for X, we only need to prove that N is the least upper bound for X (recall (3)(b) in Definition 1.1.1 in the Lecture Notes). To that end, suppose that M is an upper bound for X. Assume for a contradiction that N > M , so then ϵ := N − M > 0, and by the assumption in the question there exists x in X such that N − ϵ < x. Now observe that N − ϵ = M , but M < x ∈ X is in contradiction with the fact M is an upper bound for X. This shows that N ≤ M whenever M is an upper bound for X, hence N = sup X, as required. □ (b) Observe that A = {x : 3 < (x − 2) < 5} ∪ {x : 3 < −(x − 2) < 5} = {x : 5 < x < 7} ∪ {x : −3 > (x − 2) > −5} = {x : 5 < x < 7} ∪ {x : −1 > x > −3} = (−3, −1) ∪ (5, 7) We claim that inf A = −3. To prove this, observe that x ≥ −3 for all x ∈ A, so −3 is a lower bound for A. Next, if ϵ ∈ (0, 1), then −3 + ϵ ≥ −3 + ϵ 2 ∈ A, so −3 + ϵ is not a lower bound for A. Finally, if ϵ ≥ 1, then −3 + ϵ ≥ −3 + 1 = −2 ∈ A, so −3 + ϵ is not a lower bound for A. This show that −3 is the greatest lower bound for A, hence inf A = −3. (c)(i) Using the notation P = {0, 4, 12, 17, 20} =: {x0, x1, x2, x3, x4}, we calculate L(g, P ) = 4∑ i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = g(0)(4 − −0) + g(4)(12 − 4) + g(12)(17 − 12) + g(17)(20 − 17) = 7(4) + 19(8) + 43(5) + 58(3) = 28 + 152 + 215 + 174 = 569 1 2 and U (g, P ) = 4∑ i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = g(4)(4 − −0) + g(12)(12 − 4) + g(17)(17 − 12) + g(20)(20 − 17) = 19(4) + 43(8) + 58(5) + 67(3) = 76 + 344 + 290 + 201 = 911. Alternatively, these calculations can be done using the Riemann–Darboux Sums Calculator on Canvas, but a screenshot as in Figure 1 below must be provided. Figure 1. Two graphs of g(x) := 3x + 7 showing the areas covered by L(g, Q) = 569 and U (g, Q) = 911 for Q = {0, 4, 12, 17, 20}. 3 (c)(ii) The Riemann–Darboux Sums Calculator does not provide the required accuracy. Instead, the key point is to recognise that the function g is increasing. Suppose that n ∈ N and consider the equal-width partition Pn := {x0, x1, . . . , xn} of [0, 20] into n sub-intervals of width 20/n. The majority of the terms in U (g, Pn) − L(g, Pn) cancel, as we find that U (g, Pn) − L(g, Pn) = n∑ i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) − n∑ i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = n∑ i=1 g(xi) 20 n − n∑ i=1 g(xi−1) 20 n = 20 n [(g(x1) + · · · + g(xn)) − (g(x0) + · · · + g(xn−1))] = 20 n [g(xn) − g(x0)] = 20 n [g(20) − g(0)] = 1, 200 n . Therefore, we need a natural number n such that 1,200 n < 1 1,000 , which is the same as requiring that n > 1, 200, 000. Now choose N := 1, 200, 001. The preceding computation shows that U (g, PN ) − L(g, PN ) = 1,200 N = 1,200 1,200,001 < 1 1,000 , as required. Of course, there is no need to be so precise with the choice of N , as any natural number larger than 1,200,000 is an equally valid choice to answer this question, provided the justification above is given. Alternatively, replacing x with 3x + 7 and setting b = 20 in Exercise 1.2.7 of the Lecture Notes, we can compute L(g, Pn) = n∑ i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = n∑ i=1[3 (i−1)b n + 7] b n = 3 n−1 n b2 2 + 7b n n∑ i=1 1 = 3 n−1 n b 2 2 + 7b and U (g, Pn) = n∑ i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = n∑ i=1[3 ib n + 7] b n = 3 n+1 n b2 2 + 7b n n∑ i=1 1 = 3 n+1 n b 2 2 + 7b, so that U (g, Pn) − L(g, Pn) = 3b2 2 ( n+1 n − n−1 n ) = 3b 2 n = 1,200 n and we can then proceed as above. □ Q2. (c) For each of the functions f above, use the Riemann–Darboux sums calculator to calcu- late L(f, Pn) and U (f, Pn) when n = 5, n = 10 and n = 100, where Pn is the partition of the domain of f into n subintervals of equal width. (d) For each δ ∈ (0, 1/10), find an expression for the sums L(f, Pδ) and U (f, Pδ) when f : [−2, 2] → R, f (x) = {5, x ∈ N 3, x /∈ N and Pδ = {−2, 1 − δ, 1 + δ, 2 − δ, 2}. 4 Solution. (a)(i) For f : [0, 10] → R, f (x) = x2, P = {0, 2, 7, 10}, we calculate L(f, P ) = ∑3 i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = 0(2 − 0) + 4(7 − 2) + 49(10 − 7) = 167 and U (f, P ) = ∑3 i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = 4(2 − 0) + 49(7 − 2) + 100(10 − 7) = 553. (a)(ii) For f : [0, 10] → R, f (x) = e−x, P = {0, 1, 5, 8, 9, 10}, we calculate L(f, P ) = ∑5 i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = e−1(1 − 0) + e −5(5 − 1) + e−8(8 − 5) + e−9(9 − 8) + e−10(10 − 9) = e−1 + 4e−5 + 3e−8 + e−9 + e −10 and U (f, P ) = ∑5 i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = e−0(1 − 0) + e−1(5 − 1) + e−5(8 − 5) + e−8(9 − 8) + e−9(10 − 9) = 1 + 4e−1 + 3e−5 + e−8 + e−9. (a)(iii) For f : [0, π] → R, f (x) = sin(x), P = {0, π 2 , 3π 4 , π}, we calculate L(f, P ) = ∑3 i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = sin(0)( π 2 − 0) + sin( 3π 4 )( 3π 4 − π 2 ) + sin(π)(π − 3π 4 ) = √2 2 π 4 and U (f, P ) = ∑3 i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = sin( π 2 )( π 2 − 0) + sin( π 2 )( 3π 4 − π 2 ) + sin( 3π 4 )(π − 3π 4 ) = π 2 + π 4 + √2 2 π 4 = (3 + √2 2 ) π 4 . (d) For f : [−2, 2] → R, f (x) = {5, x ∈ N 3, x /∈ N and Pδ = {−2, 1 − δ, 1 + δ, 2 − δ, 2}, we calculate L(f, Pδ) = ∑4 i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = 3(3 − δ) + 3(2δ) + 3(1 − 2δ) + 3(δ) = 12 and U (f, Pδ) = ∑4 i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = 3(3 − δ) + 5(2δ) + 3(1 − 2δ) + 5(δ) = 12 + 6δ for each δ ∈ (0, 1/10). □ 7 Q3. It is proved in Lecture 2.1 of the Integration Lecture Notes that if f : [a, b] → [0, ∞) is a bounded function, where −∞ < a < b < ∞, and P , Q are partitions of [a, b] such that P ⊆ Q, then L(f, P ) ≤ L(f, Q). List the changes that are needed to prove that U (f, P ) ≥ U (f, Q), and in particular, explain how the inequalities m1 ≤ m ′ 1 and m1 ≤ m ′′ 1 need to be modified. Solution. We follow the same procedure as in the Lecture Notes, except instead of consid- ering the quantities m1, m ′ 1, and m ′′ 1 , we introduce M1 := sup{f (x) : x ∈ [x0, x1]}, M ′ 1 := sup{f (x) : x ∈ [x0, y]}, M ′′ 1 := sup{f (x) : x ∈ [y, x1]}. The inequalities m1 ≤ m ′ 1 and m1 ≤ m ′′ 1 are then reversed in that M1 ≥ M ′ 1 and M1 ≥ M ′′ 1 to obtain M1(x1 − x0) ≥ M ′ 1(y − x0) + M ′′ 1 (x1 − y) and thus ultimately U (f, P ) ≥ U (f, Q). □ Q4. Let f : [0, b] → [0, ∞) be defined by f (x) = x2, where b ∈ (0, ∞): (a) For each n ∈ N, let Pn = {xi : i = 0, 1, . . . , n} denote the partition of [0, b] into n subintervals of equal width. Express xi in terms of i and b. (b) Use the formula ∑k j=1 j2 = 1 6 k(k + 1)(2k + 1) to prove that L(f, Pn) = b 3 6n3 (n − 1)n(2n − 1) and U (f, Pn) = b3 6n3 n(n + 1)(2n + 1). (c) Find, with proof, the values sup{L(f, Pn) : n ∈ N} and inf{U (f, Pn) : n ∈ N}. (d) Find, with proof, the lower integral ∫ b 0 f and the upper integral ∫ b 0 f . (e) Prove that f is bounded and integrable, then find ∫ b 0 f (without using calculus). Solution. (a) For each n ∈ N, we have Pn = {0, b n , 2b n , . . . , (n−1)b n , 1} = { ib n : i = 0, 1, . . . , n}, so xi = ib n for each i ∈ {0, 1, . . . , n}. (b) For each i ∈ {0, 1, . . . , n}, we have mi = inf{x2 : x ∈ [ (i−1)b n , ib n ]} = ( (i−1)b n )2 , Mi = sup{x2 : x ∈ [ (i−1)b n , ib n ]} = ( ib n )2 . We use these to obtain L(f, Pn) = ∑n i=1 mi(xi − xi−1) = ∑n i=1 ( (i−1)b n )2 b n = b3 n3 ∑n−1 j=0 j2 = b3 n3 ∑n−1 j=1 j2 = b 3 6n3 (n − 1)n(2n − 1), 8 where we used the given sum with k = n − 1 in the penultimate equality, and U (f, Pn) = ∑n i=1 Mi(xi − xi−1) = ∑n i=1 ( ib n )2 b n = b3 n3 ∑n i=1 i2 = b3 6n3 (n + 1)n(2n + 1), where we used the given sum with k = n in the penultimate equality. (c) We can now calculate sup{L(f, Pn) : n ∈ N} = sup{ b 3 6 (2 − 3 n + 1 n2 ) : n ∈ N} = b3 3 and inf{U (f, Pn) : n ∈ N} = inf{ b3 6 (2 + 3 n + 1 n2 ) : n ∈ N} = b3 3 . To prove these facts, it suffices to observe that an := b3 6 (2 − 3 n + 1 n2 ) is an increasing sequence with limn→∞ an = b3 3 , whilst bn := b3 6 (2 + 3 n + 1 n2 ) is a decreasing sequence with limit limn→∞ bn = b3 3 . (d) Now, as {L(f, Pn) : n ∈ N} ⊆ {L(f, P ) : P is a partition of [0, b]}, we have ∫ b 0 f := sup P L(f, P ) ≥ sup n∈N L(f, Pn) = b3 3 . Moreover, as {U (f, Pn) : n ∈ N} ⊆ {U (f, P ) : P is a partition of [0, b]}, we have ∫ b 0 f := inf P U (f, P ) ≤ inf n∈N U (f, Pn) = b3 3 . We also know from Proposition 2.2.2 in the Lecture Notes that the lower integrals is always less than or equal to the upper integral, hence b3 3 ≤ ∫ b 0 f ≤ ∫ b 0 f ≤ b3 3 , which implies that b3 3 = ∫ b 0 f = ∫ b 0 f = b 3 3 . (e) The preceding equality proves that f is integrable with ∫ b 0 f = b3 6 . □ Extra Questions EQ1.
